verses.text: And when they were escaped, then they knew that the island was called Melita.
And the barbarous people shewed us no little kindness: for they kindled a fire, and received us every one, because of the present rain, and because of the cold.
And when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks, and laid \add them\add* on the fire, there came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand.

And when the barbarians saw the \add venomous\add* beast hang on his hand, they said among themselves, No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he hath escaped the sea, yet Vengeance suffereth not to live.
And he shook off the beast into the fire, and felt no harm.

Howbeit they looked when he should have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly: but after they had looked a great while, and saw no harm come to him, they changed \add their minds\add*, and said that he was a god.
In the same quarters were possessions of the chief \add man\add* of the island, whose name was Publius; who received us, and lodged \add us\add* three days courteously.
And it came to pass, that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and of a bloody flixe: to whom Paul entered in, and prayed, and laid \add his\add* hands on him, and healed him.
So when this was done, others also, which had diseases in the island, came, and were healed:
who also honoured us with many honours; and when we departed, they laded \add us\add* with such \add things\add* as were necessary.
And after three months we departed in a ship of Alexandria, which had wintered in the isle, \add whose\add* sign \add was\add* Castor and Pollux.
And landing at Syracuse, we tarried \add there\add* three days.
And from thence we fet a compass, and came to Rhegium: and after one day the south wind blew, and we came the next day to Puteoli:
where we found brethren, and were desired to tarry with them seven days: and so we went toward Rome.
And from thence, when the brethren heard of us, they came to meet us as far as Appii forum, and The three taverns: whom when Paul saw, he thanked God, and took courage.
And when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard: but Paul was suffered to dwell by himself with a soldier that kept him.

And it came to pass, that after three days Paul called the chief of the Jews together: and when they were come together, he said unto them, Men \add and\add* brethren, though I have committed nothing against the people, or customs of our fathers, \add yet\add* was I delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
Who, when they had examined me, would have let \add me\add* go, because there was no cause of death in me.
But when the Jews spake against \add it\add*, I was constrained to appeal unto Cesar; not that I had ought to accuse my nation of.
For this cause therefore have I called for you, to see \add you\add*, and to speak with \add you:\add* because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
And they said unto him, We neither received letters out of Judea concerning thee, neither any of the brethren that came shewed or spake any harm of thee.
But we desire to hear of thee what thou thinkest: for as concerning this sect, we know that every where it is spoken against.

And when they had appointed him a day, there came many to him into \add his\add* lodging; to whom he expounded and testified the kingdom of God, persuading them concerning Jesus, both out of the law of Moses, and \add out of\add* the prophets, from morning till evening.
And some believed the \add things\add* which were spoken, and some believed not.
And when they agreed not among themselves, they departed, after that Paul had spoken one word, Well spake the Holy Ghost by Esaias the prophet unto our fathers,
saying, Go unto this people, and say, Hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see, and not perceive:

for the heart of this people is waxed gross, and \add their\add* ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes have they closed; lest they should see with \add their\add* eyes, and hear with \add their\add* ears, and understand with \add their\add* heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them.
Be it known therefore unto you, that the salvation of God is sent unto the Gentiles, and \add that\add* they will hear it.
And when he had said these \add words\add*, the Jews departed, and had great reasoning among themselves.
And Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house, and received all that came in unto him,
preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those \add things\add* which concern the Lord Jesus Christ, with all confidence, no man forbidding him. The end of the Acts of the Apostles.
